data.title: Clusters and the New Economics of Competition
data.meta_description: Paradoxically, the enduring competitive advantages in a global economy lie increasingly in local thingsâ€”knowledge, relationships, and motivation that distant rivals cannot match.
data.text: Now that companies can source capital, goods, information, and technology from around the world, often with the click of a mouse, much of the conventional wisdom about how companies and nations compete needs to be overhauled. In theory, more open global markets and faster transportation and communication should diminish the role of location in competition. After all, anything that can be efficiently sourced from a distance through global markets and corporate networks is available to any company and therefore is essentially nullified as a source of competitive advantage.
